titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the University College Senior Theses MC 24
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Steven A. Walker.

editionstmt.p: This version was derived from an OCR Processed Document

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2012-09-27T14:32-0400

did.unittitle: University College Senior Theses
did.abstract: From 1894 through 1925, graduation requirements for students enrolled in the University College of Arts and Pure Science at New York University included the completion of a prescribed number of courses and the presentation of a "satisfactory thesis" on a subject selected by students in December of their senior year and approved by the faculty. The thesis related to one of the studies of a student's major field. The collection consists of 100 senior theses, 1897-1925, and one honors thesis in History, 1934.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The files are grouped into one series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of 100 senior theses, 1897-1925, and one honors thesis in history, 1934. The collection highlights student reactions to topics of the times, such as the Spanish-American War, women's suffrage, race issues, World War I, and immigration policies. On the whole, the collection provides a sample of undergraduate student research and writing in the early decades of the twentieth century.

bioghist.head: History of the Senior Thesis Requirement at the University College of Arts and Pure Science
bioghist.p: From 1894 through 1925, graduation requirements for students enrolled in the University College of Arts and Pure Science at New York University included the completion of a prescribed number of courses and the presentation of a "Satisfactory thesis" on a subject selected by students in December of their senior year and approved by the faculty. The thesis related to one of the studies of a student's major field. Upon successful completion of the thesis, the student received either his B.A., B.S., or (from 1893-1902) a Ph.B. degree. By 1925, the thesis requirement had been abandoned, but students were now given the opportunity of selecting an honors program.

Honors students announced their intentions at the end of the sophomore, or beginning of the junior year. At the time of declaration, students had to have an overall "B" average and could not receive more than one grade below a "B." For the senior year of the honors student, a thesis was also required in a subject relevant to the department in which honors was sought.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Published citations should take the following form: Identification of item, date (if known); University College Senior Theses; MC 24; box number; folder number; New York University Archives, New York University Libraries.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p:
Permission to publish materials must be obtained in writing from the:
New York University Archives
Elmer Holmes Bobst Library
70 Washington Square South
New York, NY 10012
Phone: (212) 998-2646
Fax: (212) 995-4070
E-mail: university.archives@library.nyu.edu

custodhist.head: Provenance
custodhist.p: On July 2, 1981, Professor Carl Prince presented eighteen of the theses to Professor Bayrd Still. In 1985, the remaining theses were given to archivist Tom Frusciano.

controlaccess.corpname: Washington Square College of Arts and Science.
